We actually did at one time create an internal app that lets you do
this wi=
th Picbreeder images.  We could click on a node in a CPPN and
see the patte=
rn generated at that internal node (which is like an
intermediate stage of =
development).  It's very enlightening.  One
thing it taught me is that a lo=
t of the shapes are created through
additions and subtractions, in addition=
 to compositions.  But those
additions and subtractions are very important.=
  

Unfortunately that app has not been further developed at this time and
=
is no longer compatible with Picbreeder.  Perhaps we will get back to
it so=
 that it can be made available at some point.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups=
.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> > So I'm thinking that the benchma=
rk result is less important than the
> > comprehension of how the encoding =
built its results.  CPPNs have the
> > nice property that they are fairly s=
traightforward.  You can look at
> > each hidden node and look at the inter=
mediate structure that it
> > produces.  In e.g. a GRN-based system, on the=
 other hand, it's
> > significantly more opaque and difficult to explain, a=
nd therefore more
> > difficult to bias.
> 
> Have you done this Ken? Was i=
t helpful to understand what was going on?
> 
> Do you guys have a tool tha=
t makes this easy to do? I think it would
be very

to look at the contribution of hidden nodes and

work.
